item.description: Yeah. Being in New York compounded a feeling I had been experiencing, of profound dissociation from my own life. I knew, as I wandered through museums with friends and video-chatted with Ian, that I needed to leave the tech industry. I was no longer high on the energy of being around people who so easily satisfied their desires‚Äì‚Äìon the feeling that everything was just within reach. The industry‚Äôs hubris and na√Øvet√© were beginning to grate; I had moral, political, and personal misgivings about Silicon Valley‚Äôs accelerating colonization of art, work, everyday life.

Nice intro to my programming course book. Fuck all that serious shit! Christian the absolute mad lad. From the book by C.V. Wedgwood I’m reading on the Thirty Years’ War. How to make sure you get your money if you pass a village: He had issued startling letters, suggestively burnt at the four corners, and bearing the words ‘Fire! Fire! Blood! Blood!’ to every sizeable village he passed. Or how to handle a right arm amputation graciously:

Quite a bad game on my part with some horrendous blunders at the end as the cherry on the cake. But at least I made a post game analysis for once. Some general things to remember are: dare choose the more aggressive move if possible (why not go for that sweet queen exchange???) do not play when it gets too late (but I know that rule will always be broken)

Hehe. Article about a creepy subject that isn’t so creepy. With lots of informative pictures: Could be. A disappearance begins internally, experienced en masse, but with each one‚Äîroses, photographs, and fruit follow‚Äîlong-coated, stone-faced Memory Police sweep through the village, ensuring that all traces of the disappeared concept or object is gone for good. What exactly causes disappearances is never addressed; instead, the mystery lies in how far they’ll go, and what role the Memory Police play.
